Seven years later and Facebook is still a cesspool. Now, it loudly broadcasts every click you make on the site to those that are friends with you in order to manufacture drama and profit off of it. For instance, you like a post by Pokemon official. The post shows up on Grandma's timeline because you liked it, and Grandma thinks Pokemon is the devil. She replies to the post saying as much, and the post gains traction as the cycle repeats. Now Grandma's friends are in on the argument, and people jump in to say their own piece, drawing more people in. All the while, Facebook is showing ads and profiting off the viewership and by extension, the drama.

Coming back to this, and I have noticed a new trend in Freebooting.

People create accounts on Youtube that look exactly like a user on TikTok—complete with contact details, thumbnail, blog posts... everything.

Then they start downloading all the TikTok videos and uploading them on Youtube. Now, the problem comes is that Youtube is almost as greedy as Facebook when it comes to views and ad revenue, so they are more than happy to just let such accounts roll on—even when the original TikToker contacts them to get it taken down. The only hope anyone has in actually stopping these is to get a lawyer involved.

And, when the Freebooter is finally taken down and the actual video owner can start uploading their stuff on Youtube—do you think for a moment that Youtube will give them the money all their videos have garnered already? Of course not, because Youtube is here to make their cut of ad revenue just the same as Facebook is on their service.

So, dear Kurzgesagt, would you consider changing the title of your video to "How Huge Corporations are Stealing Billions of Views" instead?

I do not see you encouraging an Alt-Tech model like FLOSS XMPP network whereby people can self-host and stick it to the big Tech. You are spoiled as are many youtubers who insist on HD. Your videos are fine in 360p, and I even have observed some in 240p if a computer is not powerful enough to playback at 2x speed without that. If they want anything more than that, they are in a utopian bubble and not looking at priority while they moan like you are doing.

I wouldn't be so sure that this has a negative effect on YouTube views. Your videos probably get more exposure if they are posted on Facebook even though you don't immediately get more views on YouTube, but if people post links to the original, that will probably be beneficial to the content creator. I like the Creative Commons model: you may copy but you have to give credit.
Personally I don't use Facebook, so I don't know what I'm missing out on that is popular over there. I could imagine there are people the opposite of me: Facebook users who don't ever go to YouTube. If you would forbid your videos to be reposted on Facebook (and people actually respect your copyright) those people will never see your videos and you'll be completely unknown to them, but if you allow reposting and require reposters to link to the original video and to your webshop, you will likely get more views and sell more stuff.

Good on you, Kurzgesagt. Even though I realize this was posted 5 years ago.
Facebook is terrible, and I think the company and the website are toxic abominations even if you forget about the personal information sales (which is inexcusable) and the video theft (which is also terrible). If Facebook needed money so badly, I'd rather they charge ten cents a month or offer a premium service.
What really gets me though, is just how utterly pathetic the website is just for doing what you'd expect a forum hosting your family and friends to do. Even on my first account to the site that I regret to inform you I used for years, stuff that I care about like what my family were doing or funny anecdotes from my friends were hidden behind tidal waves of references to "pages" I didn't follow or appreciate, and everything was just toxic and frustrating. I deleted that account after a while, finding I couldn't contribute to Zuckerberg's company's human rights abuses and future threats.
And then I made a facade account later on the website with the purpose of putting nonsense on the front, and gathering friends manually into groups - and the main feed was more pathetic than ever. It would literally have less than 8 posts on it at a time, letting me reach the bottom of my Facebook feed easily, all the time, even though it's supposed to have an "endless" stream made possible by the length of time my family had been signed up for. I didn't give a shit about what pages they commented on or interacted with, why couldn't I just see what they posted on their walls through my feed? It's such a simple concept, and yet the only 6 posts available outside of the makeshift-feed groups rarely had anything to do with that. Then I deleted my second account forever. I'm not going back.
If you care about quality of your own life with a social network, not even if you care about political issues or personal data or how videos are being stolen - if you care about the quality of your own life, I implore that you don't use Facebook anymore, and if need be switch to a smaller social network like MeWe or something - one that has common sense in its website design and gives a shit about lifekind in general.

It's not any easier to process a copyright claim when someone steals your content and shares it on youtube. 2 years ago I released a feature film I made on Amazon. 2 days later someone posted it on youtube. Youtube and google offered no legit recourse to prove the film was mine, even though i had signed contracts, raw footage,  licensing agreements, etc. The film was finally removed because the music company that licensed the music to my film filed a copyright claim with youtube. But for a little indie guy like me, I was shit out of luck. I love Kurzgesagt, but don't think for a minute that youtube/google is less evil than facebook.

Don't get me wrong, it's a terrible shame that Facebook users take a lot of content from Youtube and put in on Facebook with no benefits to the creator, but I don't think it's all bad.
There are a lot of people on Facebook who probably don't really use Youtube and wouldn't be likely to see these videos otherwise. I think all that really needs to be done is for there to be a change of outlook. If even a small proportion of the (275/1000 * 8Billion) 2.2 billion (educated guess) views of Youtube video's on Facebook per day were able to link to the original creators, it could provide a massive amount of interest in the original creators and the platform as a whole.
One of Facebook's strengths is that it makes sharing interesting content with like-minded people (friends, colleagues, e.c.t) incredibly easy, so it makes for a decent platform for the viral spreading of well made Videos (and admittedly some absolute trash). All that needs to happen is more people need to link to the sources, and more people need to be curious enough about good content to see if there's any more content of a similar vein to be found where it originated.
Surely it's to everyone's benefit to get more people interested in interesting things?


Anyway, that's my two cents.

I actually stopped supporting any youtube ads or creators. Not because i'm a dick. But because I feel that Google really needs to rework it's advert system. I don't like getting interrupted for 15-30 seconds or longer in the middle of a sentence or even in the middle of a word. Basically where Google messed up is placing video ads in the middle of videos, RANDOMLY and not in spots that support the video or creator. Using Adblock allows me to watch your entire videos, and if you were accepting Bitcoin I'd even drop you a few thousand satoshi for support. With ads enabled I QUIT watching when an add pops up mid sentence, and wreaks the entire video for me! Before Google cut my monetisation(due to the seasonal nature of my content) I was able to notice that my viewer attention plummeted RIGHT where the first mid video ad was placed!!!! I disabled the video ads prompt, but sadly it also means the short ad at the start is also disabled.

Kurzgesagt nooo.... your videos are always on point but this one is definitionally incorrect. 'Stealing' and 'copyright infringement' are two different things - they have specific legal definitions which make clear they are not the same. The term 'Freebooting' was coined on the Hello Internet podcast by Brady Haran and CGP Grey, recognising that 'copyright infringement', while technically the correct term, did not have the same emotional impact as 'stealing'. That is to say, 'Freebooting' was coined expressly to avoid the term 'stealing' when talking about this issue.

Good. This monetization trend is contrary to the principles and bases of what the Internet actually is. Just remember this: Hundreds of thousands of us create every day the software that runs the entirety of the internet, for free. From the Kernel that runs everything from the Youtube servers to your router to your Android phone, to the browser you're using, to the little libraries that make the modern web possible, like jQuery and it's thousands of useful plugins. And we do it entirely for free. The internet used to be expensive, very, very expensive. And most of the cost wasn't hardware, it was software. Say you choose to run a website to host your content, but you don't do it with a cheap GCloud server running a LAMP stack, you go the full proprietary way. Bare metal, a proprietary OS, and all the required software on top, all of it proprietary. I assure you you'll spend many times on software what you spent on hardware. But no need for that, you've got plenty of software created with love, and it's the best quality soft out there. GNU/Linux dominates the internet not because it's cheaper, but rather because it's better. Content creators got greedy after they got a taste of ad money, and they've tried to establish the idea that people have a fucking right to live off their youtube channel, or that we'll somehow get lesser quality content if they don't get paid for it. Guess what, it's the other way around. The Internet has been here for a very long time, and we had loads of quality content long before Youtube decided to share ad money with content creators, or, rather, long before Youtube itself. Still, content was plentiful, it was quality content, and we actually had a better SNR, mostly because there were no attentionwhores constantly clickbaiting us.

This gave me an idea for a video game:

A mountain called YouTube

It is an overview MMO where you start at the bottom of a volcano base. You must create your videos by cutting down "Content bushes" and "video trees", which will supply video chunks. You must then put them together, smelt them and launch them into the air, where the will dissipate and you get views on different factors. There are special abilities that can give factors, but I'll get to that later. When a video is sent up, you get views. Views give popularity points (+1 PP for every 10 views), and money (+1 money for every 1000 views.). You can use these views to buy physical skills, such as "content intelligence", where you have the ability to break down trees and bushes faster, "Video engineering", where you can make videos faster and with better views, "Channel building", which allows you to produce industrial grade video machinery, and many more. If you pass 100,00 viewers, then you start to count subscribers. A viewer now has a 69 82% chance to become a subscriber (2 subscribers = 1 dollar), however, when you reach this phase, you have to chose between 3 options. "Animator", "Lets player", or "Music creator". These options, depending on what you pick, will determine what video scraps you can obtain from bushes and trees, limiting your content, but providing stability. When you reach 100,000 subscribers, make sure to keep those videos coming, or your factory enters "The rust". The rust is an industrial setting under the volcano that scraps factories for videos and tosses the remains into the volcano crater. You have a chance to save the factory by creating a video that gets either 100 subscribers, or 1000 views. Beware though, for you only have 30 minutes to do so. If you reach 500,00 subscribers, larger channels start attacking you. You will need to create "flame warriors", Where you sacrifice a viewer to be in your defenses. If that viewer dies, however, he is gone for good. You will never see that poor sap again. You also get the ability to raid other bases for content and resources (idduno what the resources are yet). You don't have to go all fight though, because you can collaborate with a content creator. If you manage to become friends, every viewer the channel has gets a 25% chance to become a viewer and subscriber to you, plus, the channel will not attack you (unless you do so first), and will give you military aid in the event of you attacking anyone but himself. Once you reach 100,000,000 viewers, then the top channel will start attacking. The top channel sits at the very to of the volcano, with incredible power. The only way he stops attacking is by you taking him down with viewers. "How do I do that?". attack the six major support beams surrounding the base of his... er, base. once the 6 support beams are down, the channel will fall, and you can claim the top.

Now lets talk about money. Money can be used to buy stuff like "better camcorders", which would give you a 25%+ if you are a letsplayer. if you buy an "Animation tablet", then you will get a 25%+ in animation. Later on, they come with debuffs, such as "clickbaiting", which gives you 10% more viewers, but -45% respect from said viewers, meaning they are more likely to leave. If you buy a content specific item that was not in your content range, then you lose 10% consistency with videos, meaning you are more likely to pick up incompatible scraps from bushes and trees.

How to spot a stolen video in Facebook:
1.- Video starts or ends abruptly, with no credits nor intro sequence
2.- Video has a watermark from the facebook page that stole it, and doesn't mention any source in the description
3.- Has two rectangles, one at the bottom and one at the top, with text such as "OMG you wont believe this..."
4.- Overuse of emojis such as "😂", "😮", etc.

I'm surprised by this video. Usually this channel is much smarter. Let's go over why you aren't actually losing views:
1. Just because someone saw it on facebook doesn't mean they would have otherwise seen it on youtube. No differently than if I download a song does it mean I would have otherwise gone out and bought the CD. The proof of that thought process being common is that the music industry grew despite the massive amount of piracy.
2. Just because someone saw it on facebook doesn't mean they haven't already seen it on youtube.
3. People do, in fact, seek out channels due to a video they liked.

If facebook disappeared today you wouldn't see an increase in views; probably a decrease, even. I know, I know, they shouldn't be allowed to make money from your work - that's fair. But you shouldn't be pushing for them to not use them, or claiming the act is taking something away from you. It's not. Instead, you should be pushing for them to embed the original. There's no reason that both them and the creator shouldn't get view counts for it.

Youtube subscribers, obviously, do not prefer to go to Facebook to watch their favourite Youtubers, and therefore, due to this lack of competition for views, Facebook isn't stealing anything from Youtube; they're just using what Youtubers create to create their own views.
The vast majority of views Facebook receives are from videos which people DISCOVER right there on Facebook. And occasionally, a video I discover on Facebook might make such an impression on me that I will go to Youtube to watch all of the creator's original content.
They're not stealing views away from Youtube; they're allowing users to discover videos which they probably would have not have discovered if otherwise.

Several things this video either got wrong or left out.
-FB videos often don't "steal" views. The people who view those pages are likely not the same people who would be on youtube and find your videos. Because usually those pages and the video don't share the same demographic and it's an entirely different media.
(People who already view your videos and are on that page don't count, as they already view your videos. Meaning, it has no affect on them)
-While on FB, it's easier to view a video on there, rather than to click a link to youtube. While on FB, I much rather view/share/like a video that's on there, than a link to a youtube video. If you want to fight them taking your content, upload the video onto FB rather than put a link to youtube (or maybe do both). It's obvious that a site would prefer users to remain there than go elsewhere, because easier for the user and better for the site.
-The only real problem is the people who take videos and don't credit the creator. Because this does nothing for the creator, and only benefits the user. If they do credit the creator and put a link or something of the sort, then that benefits you. Because, like point one stated, they aren't "stealing" views (just videos), so you don't get affected negatively, but rather positively as you get exposure.

Also, sorry to say, but Facebook can have more exposure than youtube. With the ability to share videos with friends, comment and mention people who'd like the video, etc. It's the ideal place for users and creators (as long as everyone plays by the rules), there's no need to fight them, when you can join them and benefit from it (as with point 2).

How to spot a stolen video in Facebook:
1.- Video starts or ends abruptly, with no credits nor intro sequence
2.- Video has a watermark from the facebook page that stole it, and doesn't mention any source in the description
3.- Has two rectangles, one at the bottom and one at the top, with text such as "OMG you wont believe this..."
4.- Overuse of emojis such as "😂", "😮", etc.

good lord. if Facebook starts to have monetization for uploaders, it's only a matter of time until they get slammed with a class action infringement lawsuit if they continue their current practices of basically ignoring the issue of widespread infringement on their platform.

The completely obvious course of action is to abolish the silly thing called "copyright" and build businesses based on copying. On one side you want more complex legislation concerning things that only major computer based industry can enforce and on the other hand you want to be able to tell complex computer based industry what to do to make you rich. Talk about shooting yourself in the foot.
Also, from a point of view of law and legislation, copying IS NOT stealing, just as it isn't arson, child molesting or murder. Copying might be copyright infringement. Using the right labels seems to be the first step towards any sensible legislation, wouldn't you say?

When the dynamics of sharing economy evolve next time, be sure to support privacy and individuality and Facebook won't be the leader of social media. The side effect is of course, that you can't control who views your videos. Supporting an unfair game and then complain about losing it is just lame.
Piracy is not a victimless crime.

Never understood why people used facebook. The main reason I get when I ask is:
"It's quick and easy to keep track of friends and family"

Among other smaller nonreasons that include being more organized, simple, 'fun', and being more social. I understand the allure, but Skype does the job of keeping in touch with friends and family just fine. Without all the BS of freebooting and ads on a website. Sure, its free! But so is skype. Sure, its interesting, but boil it down and how interested are you REALLY in that 999,999,999,991st "try not to laugh" vine?

I realize that example is something of an unfair one. So simply put: consume your way, but Facebook is useless beyond your circle of actual friends. Be honest.....have you sent a message, much less spoken, to that one name at the bottom of your friends list who you added randomly a year ago? And even then, Facebook keeps shoving stuff in your face in your circle.

I sit on my computer and play video games all day, donate plasma twice a week, and enjoy my BF's company. I don't have facebook, twitter, google+, or any of the other social sites listed (besides reddit for PS2 derp posting). But I still keep in touch with family in different states via skype, still enjoy a laugh with friends while playing a game together on teamspeak. I may not go out and have a mall day with a group, but I've still got friends and family, without facebook.

What is Facebook if you take away the friends and family aspect? A platform for businesses to promote themselves and a website of ads. And a place where stolen videos make the website money. real creators may be on facebook, and I wish them the best. But choose a different platform. One not made of ad revenue from stolen videos.

I created a Facebook page specifically to share interesting YouTube channels and their content. I got roughly 80 people to like the page and even though I posted a new link every day to interesting YouTube videos like this one, it garnered almost no attention. Which would make sense if people saw the video and just didn't like it, but the stats showed that Facebook was only showing these links to maybe 6-12 out of the 80 potential viewers. (Unless of course, you pay for advertisement.)

I figured it may take a while for the page to start up, so I continued posting videos for a few months, and starting sharing the links on my personal account as well.

After all that I just started to think people didn't go to Facebook to watch YouTube.

How wrong I was...

The page is still up if anyone wants to bother scrolling through a collection of YT links. Shameless self promotion I know, but atleast I waited till the end and the page has been dead since last June as of now. Doubt anyone will read this anyhow.

You cannot "steal" digital content, so they are not a thief. Stealing requires an object you own to be taken from you. Digital content is by definition intangible and so can only be copied without authorization. Conflating copying with theft is a sneaky trick to convince people that one can own intangible content. The IP lobbyists have been using faulty arguments like this for years.

You guys should sue.  This is grossly unfair.  Band together (because I heard that this has affected a lot of YouTube content creators) and file something like a class action suit with a great plaintiffs lawyer working in conjunction with a great intellectual property lawyer.  This suit would probably be at the cutting edge of intellectual property law, so plenty of experienced practitioners and law professors would be willing to bat for you, or at least consult with you about the merits of such a suit.  Facebook and these other large corporations only understand two things--money and legal force.  If they're not willing to voluntarily play fair, then you have to legally force them to play fair.  And a class action suit is something they (and their all-powerful shareholders) will hear mighty loud and mighty clear. Personally, I'm not so sure I'd favour the use of "thievery" to describe "copyright infringement", even though it sounds like a term that's simpler/easier to digest in a short video intended for a large audience.

For example, in the linked video by +SmarterEveryDay it is erroneously implied that what is lost is the sheep itself (i.e. the video itself), when in fact what you lose out on is more akin to income that the sheep makes. What's really happening in this case is more closely related to fraud, than thievery.

Though this can pass off as nitpicking on my part, I feel it's also a meaningful note, considering the 2 videos in question (this and the one it links to) focus on educating people on a specific matter.

A year ago, I made a goofy little video where I took a children's shark book and voiced over the pictures. Not the most original idea -- it's something a lot of people do, and it was just something that I made in like five minutes with no production value whatsoever just to make a couple friends laugh, but it went on to garner millions and millions of views... all of which are from people that ripped it and uploaded it to their Facebook pages. At first, I didn't think much of it. The video was getting attention, and what made me happy was seeing all the comments from people that really seemed to enjoy it -- sharing it with their friends, saying how it brightened up their day, etc... I was thrilled that a silly little thing like that could do that for people. I didn't mind that my official upload of it only had an extremely small fraction of those views. After a while, though, I started getting a little bitter. I don't make videos in hopes of "getting rich" off of them, I make them because I enjoy it and I love making people smile... but when I realized just how much I missed out on by having all those views go to uploads from other people who stole it, it felt like a huge slap to the face. I realized how much exposure I missed out on, and how much the ad revenue on a video like that could have really helped me out. Again, I can't stress this enough -- I'm not in this for the money, but being able to earn a living off of this stuff is kind of the goal. I know that might sound contradictory, but the reason for that is so I can keep working on creating content full time and not have to rely on working shitty day jobs to pay my bills. With a video as big as this one turned out to be, it totally could have kickstarted all that and helped me get my foot in the door, so to speak. It would have helped me build a larger audience, draw more attention to my other work, and helped make it so that all my time and energy could be applied to doing what I love, and I felt like I was kind of robbed of that.

The biggest slap to the face is that people don't even bother crediting the original creators. I mean, you're stealing their fucking content. The LEAST you could do is throw them a bone, and not doing so just adds insult to injury. What stings the most is that if they truly felt compelled to share something, they could EASILY just share a link to the original upload; it only takes a couple clicks. Instead, they go out of their way to rip the video, be it with a YouTube video converter or screen capture software, and present that shit as if they had done it. Shit like this needs to stop, and it's pretty upsetting that it likely never will. I've accepted the fact that I missed out on a great opportunity, but it's the principle of the thing that really drives me up the wall. What these people are doing is stealing, and that isn't cool.

Finally, people can speak out against this blatant piracy. Piracy is just theft with charades. Sure "the original still exists," but the outcome is the same. Someone else gets profit or other gain from ripping content from its source, while the creator gets none of it. And don't fucking call it "exposure" Because you're still getting 100% of all the views that video gets, and the amount of "exposure" that someone gets when you don't give them credit, or provide direct links ends up being less helpful than pirating the content is hurtful. And don't say "well it should be free to use in the first place." No, it's whatever price the creator gives it. And the price IS based on what people will pay for it, or else it wouldn't make money. Piracy is petty.

It's important to remember that video sites like YouTube, Blip and Newgrounds are somewhat replacing the highly monopolized studio/distributor model of TV and film. The fact that this new way of securing funding for creative endeavors allows incredible creative freedom and room for bold innovation. The act of ripping and sharing on Facebook and similar sites with their own player (in which the views do not contribute toward's the original author's ad revenue) is no more than a stain and a hindrance that ultimately helps no one but the site like Facebook itself. The content creator is robbed of funding which may lead to her or his inability to create more content to reach us, the viewers.

At this point, I think the real question is: should there be further legislation enacted to specifically protect small content creators from these kinds of situations? If so, how can it be achieved? How would it be worded? It would take massive public support as the studios that want to see an end to grassroots competition would likely lobby against them.

I sympathize with your plight. As the content creator, you deserve the revenue generated from your creations. Unfortunately content creators on Youtube today are suffering the same copyright infringements that itself served as the cornerstone for Youtube's success.

At one time, I subscribed to a sight called Atomfilms (back before they were acquired and re-purposed by Viacom). Atomfilms hosted extremely well done short films and animations submitted by creators who were paid based on hits. Youtube had absolutely no problem with the idea that these videos were copied and re-posted on Youtube accounts. They employed a copyright violation complaint system that was even more difficult to use than Facebook's today. For Atomfilms, the loss of revenue eventually discouraged content creators to the point they gave up in large numbers.

Unfortunately, that is the way the internet works, and content creators must find ways to maximize where they do get revenue. Your first comment is a good step.

In my view the biggest offender is Youtube.

They hide behind the principle of "if we do wrong tell us and we will stop" rather than "we will not do any wrong".

Its not enough to respond to take down notices they should be proactive in not allowing copyrighted material to be uploaded without consent.

How is a small 5 person small production team supposed to monitor Youtube to make sure they are not being infringed - you could employ one person to search all the time and they still would not be able to catch everything.

Video content takes time and money to produce and there are precious few producers of professional content of quality - bastions of quality like the British BBC are fighting for funding in their own country whilst their content is regulary stolen and posted on Youtube and Youtube are the ones who benefit. The BBC do issue take down notices but appear to only have time or will to do so for their latest content, plenty of older science and history content remains online - when official BBC content is placed on Youtube by the BBC it is usually only in the form of a taster with incomplete content - it is clear by the BBC's actions that they do not favour full scale release of their content on Youtube yet this is precisely what happens.

We are creating a new generation who think that because they have access to some free services like Google that any bit of media they can lay their hands on is effectively theirs to do with as they please. Someone writes above that educational content should be free - WHY it costs money to produce eductional content just like any other - if they feel this way they should go away and work for nothing whilst their family cope with a lost wage and post their own free content but they should not use infantile arguments of "access to everything" to argue that others should effectively work without full reward. None of us has the right to insist that an individual or company give us anything for free and in turn most of us have to ask for money in return for our endevours - its called the cost of living and a decent wage.

I really look forwards to the day when global musicians or film producers take a class action on Youtube and stop this global theft - if it continues or grows then the incentive to produce quality professional content will diminish. Only a huge US corporation could pull off - any small company being so cavalier with other people's copyright would have been nailed to the tree years ago. Its time for Youtube to stop shifting responsibility onto users or arguing that responding to take down notices is the end of their responsibility - they create the conditions for copyright theft and its time they were held responsible for it.

Jackson Galaxy shared the stolen version on FB a month later and I was tagged by family members in it, so I contacted the guy that stole it to please source it. This is a great summary of the freebooting problem that we creators face.   I would also like to point out that smaller creators have this problem with Youtube, too.   YT does not grant their Content ID system to smaller-time channels, they only do this for the biggest and most popular channels.  The worst right now are compilation makers which steal the most popular videos from multiple small-time channels, diverting views and subscribers away from the originals.  Without Content ID, these must be manually searched for on a daily basis and taken down one-by-one using YT's manual DMCA form.  To date, I have spent more time policing for my videos on Youtube than I have shooting and editing the original content.   I have been rejected twice for Content ID, despite over 700 DMCA takedowns (all manually discovered) issued over the past 2 years.

First of all, Facebook as a company cannot be blamed if individuals steal content. Facebook is NOT cheating. Plagiarists and content-pirates are the ones who are cheating. Give Facebook credit for having put in a system of reporting and accountability. I have had issues myself, I found the Facebook support team to be very helpful and the issues were resolved in a few hours, not four days as this video will have you believe.

Even if they take time, consider the fact that Facebook has literally BILLIONS of viewers. They are doing a very good job despite the overwhelming volume.

I agree, the system is not perfect, but the social media boom is only like a decade old. There is still a lot to learn. The system is imperfect and is evolving into a better beast everyday.

“They rig their algorithm so that videos uploaded into their player are preferred to YouTube links.”
First of all, there is no way for us to verify this outlandish claim. Regardless, they prefer their own player, what's the harm in that? Most video-makers, including myself, bypass YouTube completely and upload videos directly to Facebook. Hey, and you know who else prefers their own player? Vimeo. Dailymotion. Metacafe. Vine. YouPorn. RedTube.

"Users should be kept as long as possible on the site, so Facebook can show them as many ads as possible.”
So? Isn't that how the Google works? In fact, isn't that how the internet works?

“This is after all their business model.”
Well, duh! They are a multi-billion dollar corporation with salaries to pay and infrastructure to maintain. Why malign them for making money?

And regarding the auto-play, Facebook has an option to disable auto-play. YouTube does not.

“A whole group of people have built their online presence around stealing other people's work.”
The maker of the video contradicts his earlier accusation with this statement. 'People' steal work, not Facebook. Facebook is not cheating.

“The thief doesn't have to fear any negative consequences at all.”
Nonsense. The thief can be sued for copyright infringement if the original content creator bothers to do so. Again the video-maker contradicts himself at 04:30 by saying, “Alert the original creator, because only they can file a copyright report.” Sounds like consequences to me.

Throughout the narrative, the maker of this video seems to malign 'big corporations' like Facebook who make 'billions of dollars'. Big corporations provide employment and run economies. Stop viewing them as villains.

Facebook, if utilized properly, can be very helpful to upcoming artistes and content creators. I personally have generated a lot of business and made a lot of money through Facebook marketing. Our generation is very blessed to have the boon of social media. It has leveled the playing field and thanks to this, nobodies like me have a shot at making it big (if we are talented enough) by getting an opportunity to put out content that the entire world can see.

+In a Nutshell - Kurzgesagt
I understand you position, and you are in principle completely right, no doubt about that, BUT ... nobody is STEALING from you (or any other content creator), as the word 'steal' implies that the discretionary power over an object is removed from the owner, which it is in this case clearly not. So nothing is STOLEN, but there was an illegal reproduction of protected intellectual property. That doesn't make it in anyway better or right, but if the affected person is not even able to correctly describe what happened to him, this becomes a somewhat questionable statement. Especially as stealing has a negative emotional connotation, one might get the impression, that the message is emotionally and rationally target, which would directly lead to the conclusion, that the emitter itself might think, that rational part of the message might not be strong enough to convince recipients nd therefore turns to an emotional targeting. By using proper wording, such ideas can be avoided.
So, I can perfectly understand, if you are pissed if others simply take your content and make money out of it (a side question you might think about is, why are they able to do so, and you are not ? Are there options to increase your distribution strategy ?) You have obviously every right to be very very unhappy about it. but you should stick with the right wording. Nobody STEALS from you, but makes money as a freerider by violating protected intellectual property via illegal reproduction. Again, that doesn't make it better, but it is not identical.

If a video gets stolen, file a claim with facebook. Just like youtube they have to have a notice and takedown system to prevent the hosting of copyrighted material. If they don't comply with the DMCA then they can get hit with contributory infringement. To qualify for the DMCA safe harbor they must: Have a notice and takedown system for reporting and removing copyrighted material; prevent repeat infringers (generally done through an ip block or something to the same effect); actual enforcement of their system; and they have to have an email on file at the copyright office. If facebook is not complying with DMCA then you as a copyright holder can bring suit against them. Youtube got out of a suit because of how quick and effective their system is I don't know if anyone has tried to sue facebook but their notice and takedown system is definitely lacking.

From the Facebook help forum:

For computers:
Go to your options drop-down menu in the top right.
Click "Settings"
Select the "Videos" link on the left.
Turn the "Auto-Play Videos" from "ON" to "OFF"

For Phones and tablet apps:
You can adjust your auto-play settings to On, Wi-Fi only or Off. If auto-play is On, the data used depends on the amount of time you spend watching a video. If you scroll past an auto-play video in News Feed, your phone will use less data than if you stop to watch it for a longer period of time. If auto-play is set to Wi-Fi only, no data will be used.

This is a good point, and I understand that this is what's happening now and glad that you addressed it. However, from an ideological point of view,  it seems like a lot of the videos that get stolen & receive massive views, are of kittens doing funny things, vines, or pranks being done etc, all "low" quality content. This type of content does almost nothing to advance human knowledge and inevitably contributes to the information overload on the internet drowning out the "real" high quality content, which lowers our expectation of what we can gain from the internet itself, leading a lot of people to sit in front of the screen for hours on end consuming this low quality content instead of being a productive or innovative member of society. Someone that records themselves reacting to video games, or of them saying or doing something rude to the public as a prank does not deserve as much payment as the scientists who make important discoveries every day. It seems like the internet has started rewarding low quality content more and more over the past two decades, which is why we're seeing more and more crap. The payment should be intrinsic in the number of views themselves without any expectation to monetize. Say a marketing company put a lot of creativity into an advertisement and made it extremely engaging. If it gets millions of views, (stolen or not), the creativity is translated into viewership. The monetization comes from how well the advertisement can funnel the viewers into customers, making the stealing of videos sound funny. Ey Kurzgesagt! "Stolen" isn't exactly the appropriate word for this. I do understand that many of the videos were downloaded and re uploaded without permission or credit to the original creators but that's still not theft. It's also not theft in a sense that the reuploaders gets revenue from content they didn't create. Facebook doesn't allow uploaders to receive any revenue from them no matter what.

Perhaps "copytheft" would be a more appropriate term as it has received more acceptance in legal terminology but still not technically correct as the word theft indicates removing property from someone's property. A newly emerged term that has been popular when it comes to describing this practice is "freebooting" and it's just perfect for this use case. Perhaps you could help popularizing a new term that fits the situation rather than using verbs wrongly.

Sure, the content creators here on YouTube own the rights to the videos they make, but in a way, so does Google since Google owns YouTube. Google could sue Facebook for enabling its users to profit off of stealing content from YouTube users, just like music companies have sued YouTube in the past for enabling people to steal music and re-upload them as videos. If Google did a significant lawsuit against Facebook I could imagine Facebook striking some sort of deal in which Facebook would forfeit a percentage of the add revenue they make off of stolen content to Google, who would then give a percentage of that to the creators of the content. With the power of Google lawyers behind us, I think we'd be in a much stronger position than trying to fight Facebook as individual content creators.

This is the same argument against piracy. Copying / duplicating is not stealing. Firstly, you are not depriving people to enjoy your content by creating another copy of it (the original is not removed by taking it like a real world object). Secondly, those people were never part of your audience to begin with. If a post on Facebook contains a link to Youtube, it would just be ignored.

Follow this dark park of censorship and you will find yourself in 1984. Sharing is what internet was supposed to be about. Since, you will have cognitive dissonance trying to understand my argument, I will present you with other solutions:

1. Upload your videos to facebook yourself,
2. Put a huge watermark in the middle of your videos,
3. Don't create digital content that can be consumed by everyone.

It's not just Facebook, either. So many news sites also steal video content, repackage it in their own player and force ads on it without paying the creator, and often without mentioning them at all. It's a terrible thing to do to the people who depend on ad revenue from the content they produce. But just like Facebook, these sites get away with it because they know the vast majority of their views are going to come in before they get into trouble and are forced to take the video down.

Another issue is when people make gifs of videos as it effectively extracts the best parts of a video without lending credit to the creator. Also, if they do link back to the original video, it is unlikely that anyone will actually watch it as they have already gotten what the spoilers or what they wanted out of the gif.
